1.text: Pinching with two fingers, pick up the yarn roughly 6-8" from the end.

2.text: Twist your fingers clockwise to make the yarn cross over, forming a loop.

3.text: Put your two fingers inside the loop, expanding it out.

4.text: Using the fingers in the loop, grab the standing yarn and pull it  partially through.

5.text: Pull the tail of the yarn to tighten the knot about halfway.

6.text: Slide your knitting needle or crochet hook into the loop and pull both ends of yarn tight.

7.text: Pick up the yarn approximately 12 centimeter (4.7 in) (5in) from the end.

8.text: Create a loop by taking the long end of the yarn (standing line) and winding it over the top of the shorter end (tail).

9.text: Using your right hand, pick up the standing line of yarn to form another bight.

10.text: Feed this second bite through the back of the loop.

11.text: Pull on the tail of the knot to tighten the first loop around the second.

12.text: Feed your knitting needles or crochet hook into the remaining loop and pull the long end of the yarn to close the loop over the needle.

13.text: Pull out about ten inches of yarn from your yarn ball.

14.text: Make a 1" loop in the yarn by tucking the end of the yarn under the rest of the yarn.

15.text: Flip the loop back down so it lays on top of the rest of the yarn.

16.text: Pick up the yarn inside the loop and pull it through.

17.text: Pull the end of the yarn to get the knot tight, keeping the loop at the top open.

18.text: Slip the knot onto a knitting needle or crochet hook and pull both ends to tighten the knot.
